body: Need someone to change a timeout of stressNewTest and re-run it, to have more time to run it all. Thanks!
The failing build and tests for this PR are blocked waiting for [this backport](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/6679) which should allow them to pass.

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Use of externally\-controlled format string

> Need someone to change a timeout of stressNewTest and re-run it, to have more time to run it all. Thanks!

Boosted timeouts by 10x and retriggered, hope it doesn't actually take 4 days ;)

Some small refactoring changes aside, this seems to just be a revert of GEODE-9411. Is there some middle ground solution that would prevent the spurious exception logging from Netty but preserve the behaviour where we don't close the connection if we hit any `IOException` at all, regardless of the origin?

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging d0310efca88f1b8f462ca840ab9d6cf5031821a1 into 2c502d0ec41d2ae894a7a2e91282ad6d2983e7c3 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-fd8da486cb3642d8dd118c287a343a05557a4a8a)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Potential input resource leak

After sleeping on it, I think I've come up with a better solution, which moves the check for the dummy member names out of the `OrderedSetEntry` class and into a new class, `DummyOrderedSetEntry` which is only used in ZCOUNT, thus moving those comparisons out of the hot path.

Since `IOException`s are checked, the implication is that they may be recoverable. However, in this case since netty is telling us about this problem, there isn't anything we can do about it. We're being told that the client is gone and we can perform any necessary cleanup.

> Since `IOException`s are checked, the implication is that they may be recoverable. However, in this case since netty is telling us about this problem, there isn't anything we can do about it. We're being told that the client is gone and we can perform any necessary cleanup.

Aah, I see now. As long as we can be sure that we only see an `IOException` when the client is gone, and not in other cases, then it should be fine to just revert the entire commit for GEODE-9411. If we think there might be cases where an `IOException` is thrown and we don't want to close the connection, maybe we could check for the "Connection reset by peer" message in the exception and close if we see that?
This will be overwritten by the next release (either 1.13.4 or 1.14.0), is that ok?  Or does this need to be pinned in perpetuity?

> This will be overwritten by the next release (either 1.13.4 or 1.14.0), is that ok? Or does this need to be pinned in perpetuity?

Yes, that is fine. this is a temporary fix to move the baseline past that regression so that tests stop failing in CI. The next release will also be passed that regression, so it will also be ok. We just need the baseline to be something after the dependency version bumps

> We just need the baseline to be something after the dependency version bumps

But 1.13.3 has the same jetty dependency bump...

> > We just need the baseline to be something after the dependency version bumps
> 
> But 1.13.3 has the same jetty dependency bump...

1.13.3 does not contain the dependency bump, which is a problem. if 1.13.4 does not contain the dependency bump and is the next released version, then we will need to keep the baseline as the above commit until a version that contains it. so definitely 1.14.
Closing in favor of a cleaned up PR.
I've tried to break this PR into one commit for core changes and another commit for test-related changes

Closing as unnecessary and closing out the ticket.

When I left for vacation two weeks ago, the baseline was 1.13.2, which was causing the performance issue. During those two weeks, the baseline was moved to 1.13.3, which resolves the performance issue. So setting the baseline to this specific commit is no longer necessary. This change was made by the following commit: 5b5748300fb7b783e1a75c54f0dda750b89cc4f5

related to: https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/6685

The above PR has comments explaining the final outcome of this whole investigation into the performance degradation. I am closing this PR for the same reasons as the other one.

More details and data can be found here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-9340

I removed the testClearTime time test, because injecting a Statistics Clock into the test cache would not be easy and this stat is already tested via JUnit. Though mocking is used for the StatisticsClock there.

Closing in favor of a complete revert.
@albertogpz I find it confusing that the `--cancel` command option can optionally accept a boolean value, when it could be simply present or absent. What is the use case for `--cancel=false`?

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Use of externally\-controlled format string

> @albertogpz I find it confusing that the `--cancel` command option can optionally accept a boolean value, when it could be simply present or absent. What is the use case for `--cancel=false`?

I agree. It would not make sense to use --cancel=false.

The normal use would be to either specify --cancel or not use --cancel at all. But the `CliOption` for boolean parameters class does not offer, as far as I know, the possibility to have an options without values.
If you know a way to do it, please, let me know.

> > @albertogpz I find it confusing that the `--cancel` command option can optionally accept a boolean value, when it could be simply present or absent. What is the use case for `--cancel=false`?
> 
> I agree. It would not make sense to use --cancel=false.
> 
> The normal use would be to either specify --cancel or not use --cancel at all. But the `CliOption` for boolean parameters class does not offer, as far as I know, the possibility to have an options without values.
> If you know a way to do it, please, let me know.

Thank you for explaining that CliOption allows the boolean parameter to be specified -- that would explain why I've encountered similar constructs when documenting other gfsh commands. In my edit of the docs for this command, I will omit that complication. I find it unhelpful, particularly when trying to describe the default behavior.

> > > @albertogpz I find it confusing that the `--cancel` command option can optionally accept a boolean value, when it could be simply present or absent. What is the use case for `--cancel=false`?
> > 
> > 
> > I agree. It would not make sense to use --cancel=false.
> > The normal use would be to either specify --cancel or not use --cancel at all. But the `CliOption` for boolean parameters class does not offer, as far as I know, the possibility to have an options without values.
> > If you know a way to do it, please, let me know.
> 
> Thank you for explaining that CliOption allows the boolean parameter to be specified -- that would explain why I've encountered similar constructs when documenting other gfsh commands. In my edit of the docs for this command, I will omit that complication. I find it unhelpful, particularly when trying to describe the default behavior.

We could change the documentation of the command to say:
`[--cancel]` instead of `[--cancel(=value)?]` but the command would allow to set a value anyway.

> > > > @albertogpz I find it confusing that the `--cancel` command option can optionally accept a boolean value, when it could be simply present or absent. What is the use case for `--cancel=false`?
> > > 
> > > 
> > > I agree. It would not make sense to use --cancel=false.
> > > The normal use would be to either specify --cancel or not use --cancel at all. But the `CliOption` for boolean parameters class does not offer, as far as I know, the possibility to have an options without values.
> > > If you know a way to do it, please, let me know.
> > 
> > 
> > Thank you for explaining that CliOption allows the boolean parameter to be specified -- that would explain why I've encountered similar constructs when documenting other gfsh commands. In my edit of the docs for this command, I will omit that complication. I find it unhelpful, particularly when trying to describe the default behavior.
> 
> We could change the documentation of the command to say:
> `[--cancel]` instead of `[--cancel(=value)?]` but the command would allow to set a value anyway.

Yes, that's my plan. The user guide does not have to provide an exhaustive list of every conceivable code path. In this case, we can direct the user to the most straightforward usage and leave it at that.

> @albertogpz
> Thanks for writing the docs, Alberto. I would like to request a few edits.
> As discussed, I've modified the description of the cancel option. I also re-ordered some of the text, formatted prerequisites as a bulleted list, and caught a couple of typos. Attached is a zip file containing:
> 
>     * My edited version of wan_copy_region.html.md.erb
> 
>     * Changes only, in the form of a diff
>       [GEODE-9369-dbarnes.zip](https://github.com/apache/geode/files/6804470/GEODE-9369-dbarnes.zip)

Not sure what this would skip, maybe LGTM?  GitHub does not initiate our concourse-based checks, so it has no power to skip them.  Our PR resource does support skipping checks with `[ci skip]` or `[skip ci]` which perhaps could be useful on intermediate commits, but the final commit of a PR does need to run and pass all required checks or it won't be mergeable.

Hi,

- InProgress statistics is the same as messagesWaitingToQueue statistic.
- messagesBeingQueued is not needed, since we have existing messageQueueSize statistic.
- Only addition could be messagesBeingQueuedTime

> That seems reasonable. Odd that this is the first we have seen of this kind of problem. One would have thought other default ports would have this problem. But perhaps, this test is flawed. Perhaps breaking it into a test of the default port number and a test of the starting up on a specified port would be more appropriate then altering our test framework?

@mhansonp I think it started appearing because Dale removed use of Docker for these tests.

> Odd that this is the first we have seen of this kind of problem. One would have thought other default ports would have this problem.

It's a consequence of two things. First, we are no longer dockerizing test workers. Until a few weeks ago, each test worker ran in a separate docker container, and within each container fewer processes were competing for ports. Now that dozens of concurrently running tests compete for the same ports, we will see more port conflicts like this.

Second, very few tests use default ports, so there are likely to be few conflicts… except in stress tests, which pit multiple instances of a test against each other.

> But perhaps, this test is flawed. Perhaps breaking it into a test of the default port number and a test of the starting up on a specified port would be more appropriate then altering our test framework?

I chose this approach because it affects only tests that explicitly test the use of default ports. And my guess (or perhaps merely my hope) is that very few tests do that: Only one per service. So very few tests will use this technique to avoid stress. I hope.

As for altering the test framework, my assessment (for now) is that including these few tests in stress test runs isn't worth the extra complexity in the test framework.

> As for altering the test framework, my assessment (for now) is that including these few tests in stress test runs isn't worth the extra complexity in the test framework.

I suggested that we modify this test to be repeated test capable rather than adding a new category which you have done.

E.g. Pulling the default port in into a default port test. Then modify this code to test that it works fine with a configured port. I am not very attached to this idea, but it seems cleaner. Because then the redis code will get repeat testing.

> I suggested that we modify this test to be repeated test capable rather than adding a new category which you have done.

Ah. I misread "then" as meaning "and then," and my misreading changed the entire meaning of what you wrote. Sorry about that.
